Looping in Ruby versus JavaScript Cheatsheet

Looping in Ruby is quite different than JavaScript. There are a lot of built-in methods that can be confusing at first, but, I my opinion, make programming much simpler. JavaScript requires much more explicit iteration, as we'll see in the below comparisons. We will be comparing .each, while, and .map methods.

A popular Ruby looping method is the each method, which can be replaced with a simple for loop in JavaScript. 


          # Ruby "each" iterator


          myarray.each {

          |items|

          puts items

          }



        

          // JavaScript "for" loop
          for (i = 0; i < myarray.length; i++)
          {
          console.log(myarray[i]);
          }
          // OR
          myarray.forEach(function(n) {
          console.log(n);
          })
          // OR
          for (element in myarray){
          console.log(element)
          }

Both Ruby and JavaScript have while methods that operate similarly on a data collection. 


          # Ruby "while" loop
          counter = myarray.length
          while counter > 0 do
            puts "myarray[counter-1]"
            counter -= 1
          end

        

          // JavaScript "while" loop
          counter = myarray.length
          while (counter > 0)
          {
            console.log "myarray[counter-1]";
            counter--;
          }

Ruby and JavaScript both have map methods that work on arrays. 


         # Ruby "map" method

          myarray.map{ |item|
          item*2
          }
        

          //JavaScript "map" method
          var doubles = myarray.map(
          function(num) {
            return num * 2;
            });

Any comments or suggestions? Get in touch!
